node.title: Why Hans Zimmer Wonâ€™t Be Making Music for the Metaverse
node.description: The composer discusses how streaming and A.I. are transforming movie music.
node.content: ["Hans Zimmer has spent his career scoring cinematic worlds, from the ancient Rome of \u201cGladiator\u201d to the futuristic landscape of \u201cDune.\u201d So what does the metaverse sound like to him? \u201cIt sounds like just some giant, horrible, dehumanizing mess right now,\u201d he says.", "[You can listen to this episode of \u201cSway\u201d on Apple, Spotify, Google or wherever you get your podcasts.]", "Zimmer sees tech\u2019s influence everywhere in music. He posits that from drums to violins to synthesizers, \u201cevery piece that we use other than the human voice is a piece of technology.\u201d But he\u2019s also cleareyed about how innovations like artificial intelligence and streaming don\u2019t fix underlying issues of fairness in compensation: \u201cThe people who have access to the distribution systems really still always will hold the cards.\u201d", "In this conversation, Kara Swisher talks to Zimmer about his process for composing the score for \u201cDune\u201d and why he says finding out that the movie would premiere simultaneously in theaters and on HBO Max was a \u201ccrushing moment.\u201d They also discuss how composers can adapt to the shifting demands of viewers and a streaming economy \u2014 and what he\u2019s working on next.", "(A full transcript of the episode will be available midday on the Times website.)", "Kara Swisher is working on a podcast for HBO, which is part of WarnerMedia and is a major player in streaming media."]
